This week in The New York Times, I read an article entitled In Charleston, Raw Emotion at Hearing for Suspect in Church Shooting by Nikita Stewart and Richard Pérez-Peña. A twenty-one year old man named Dylann Storm Roof, was charged with murder for shooting nine African-American people during a Bible study in a church in Charleston, North Carolina. Loved ones of the victims were allowed to speak at Roof’s bail hearing. The author quoted Nadine Collier, the daughter of seventy year old Ethel Lance in the article in which Nadine stated during trial directed to Dylann Roof (the murderer), “You took something very precious away from me. I will never talk to her again. I will never hold her hand again. But I forgive you. And have mercy on your soul.” I believe that Collier was not only trying to teach Roof a lesson but was also trying to show that there is more room for forgiveness than hate. I enjoyed reading this article because of the positive message it teaches everyone. No good comes from hate and anger. We must love and forgive. I find it extremely disturbing that Roof could go into the church during Bible study and sit with people for a whole hour and then go ahead and start shooting them. Although people are hearing this story and are talking about hate crimes and gun control, I wish they would talk more about the example of love and forgiveness that these victims families have demonstrated amazingly during this horrible time.
